text: They only consult to cast him down from his excellency: they delight in lies: they bless with their mouth, but they curse inwardly. Selah.
text_kjv: They only consult to cast him down from his excellency: they delight in lies: they bless with their mouth, but they curse inwardly. Selah.
text_niv: They fully intend to topple himfrom his lofty place;they take delight in lies.With their mouths they bless,but in their hearts they curse. Selah
text_esv: They only plan to thrust him down from his high position. They take pleasure in falsehood. They bless with their mouths, but inwardly they curse. Selah
text_nlt: They plan to topple me from my high position.They delight in telling lies about me.They praise me to my facebut curse me in their hearts. Interlude
text_msg: Anthills plotting to bring down mountains,far gone in make-believe.You talk a good line,but every "blessing" breathes a curse.
text_nasb: They have counseled only to thrust him down from his high position; They delight in falsehood; They bless with their mouth, But inwardly they curse. Selah.
context: Psalm 62, attributed to David, likely reflects a period of turmoil and conspiracy against him, possibly during Absalom's rebellion or another instance where his kingship was challenged. Kings in the ancient Near East, including Israel, were viewed as divinely appointed and possessed an 'excellency' or dignity derived from God's favor and position. This wasn't merely physical strength or political power but included moral standing and spiritual authority. To 'cast him down' meant not only to depose him from his throne but also to undermine his reputation and erode public trust. Lies and deceit were common tools in political intrigue, used to manipulate public opinion and sow discord. The practice of speaking blessings while harboring curses reflects a deep-seated hypocrisy, a common feature of courtly life and power struggles. The 'Selah' serves as a musical interlude or a call to pause and reflect on the preceding words, emphasizing their importance. In David's time, honor and reputation were paramount. A king's standing with his people and with God was directly related to his ability to rule effectively and maintain stability. The presence of enemies actively plotting his downfall, while feigning loyalty, would have created an atmosphere of constant suspicion and vulnerability, forcing David to rely heavily on God for protection and guidance. The Psalm itself functions as a declaration of trust in God amidst such treacherous circumstances.
meaning: Psalm 62:4 unveils the insidious nature of David's enemies and their methods. Their 'consultation' isn't for genuine counsel or constructive debate, but a calculated conspiracy to bring about his ruin. 'Excellency' refers not just to his royal position, but also to the favor and blessing he received from God. These enemies sought to strip him of that divine validation. The 'delight in lies' exposes their moral corruption. They weren't motivated by truth or justice, but by a twisted pleasure in deceit and manipulation. The stark contrast between their outward blessings and inward curses highlights their hypocrisy. They feigned respect and loyalty while secretly harboring malice and plotting destruction. This verse reveals a profound spiritual battle. David's enemies were not merely political opponents; they were agents of spiritual darkness attempting to undermine God's chosen leader. The 'blessing with their mouth' represents a superficial, insincere facade, masking the 'curse inwardly,' which speaks to their true intent and malevolent desires. This duplicity reveals a profound disconnect between outward appearance and inward reality, a common theme in the Psalms and throughout Scripture. It underscores the importance of discerning the spirits and not being deceived by outward appearances. The 'Selah' invites us to contemplate the gravity of this duplicity and to recognize its presence in our own lives and in the world around us.
application: Psalm 62:4 remains profoundly relevant today. In our modern context, we encounter similar forms of deceit and manipulation in various arenas â€“ politics, workplaces, social media, and even within religious communities. The 'consultation' to cast someone down can manifest as workplace gossip campaigns, online smear campaigns, or political maneuvering designed to undermine an opponent's reputation. The 'delight in lies' is rampant in a world saturated with misinformation and propaganda. We must cultivate discernment and critical thinking skills to avoid being swayed by falsehoods. The 'blessing with their mouth, but they curse inwardly' is perhaps the most pervasive form of hypocrisy. It can appear as superficial politeness masking underlying resentment or passive-aggressive behavior designed to inflict emotional harm. In the age of social media, it's easy to portray a false image of perfection and happiness while secretly struggling with insecurity and discontent. As Christians, we are called to be different. We must strive for authenticity and integrity in our words and actions. This means speaking the truth in love, even when it's difficult, and guarding our hearts against bitterness and resentment. We can apply this verse by examining our own motives and intentions. Are we truly blessing others with our words, or are we harboring hidden resentments? Are we contributing to gossip and slander, or are we defending the truth and speaking well of others? Cultivating genuine relationships built on trust and honesty is crucial in combating the spirit of deceit. Regularly reflecting on God's word and seeking His guidance can help us discern the difference between truth and falsehood and to avoid the trap of hypocrisy. We need to be aware of the manipulative tactics of others and seek God's wisdom to navigate these situations with grace and integrity.
prayer: Heavenly Father, expose the hidden agendas of those who seek to undermine truth and righteousness. Grant me discernment to recognize deception and the courage to stand against it. Help me to examine my own heart, revealing any hypocrisy or hidden resentment that may be lurking within. Purify my motives, that my words and actions may reflect your love and grace. Give me the strength to speak the truth in love, even when it's difficult. Protect me from the schemes of the enemy and guide me in your ways. May my life be a testament to your truth and integrity. I pray for those who are being targeted by deceitful schemes, that they may find comfort and protection in you. Let them not be discouraged by the lies of others, but instead, be strengthened by your unwavering faithfulness. Help me to be a source of encouragement and support to those who are suffering injustice. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The 'excellency' mentioned refers not only to David's position as king, but also to the dignity and authority given to him by God. It's a divinely-ordained position.

faqs.answer: The phrase 'bless with their mouth, but they curse inwardly' signifies hypocrisy. It is an outward show of respect masking inner hatred and malicious intent.
faqs.question: Q2

faqs.answer: The 'consult' implies deliberate and planned action. The enemies gathered and conspired together to orchestrate a specific outcome, that is to cast down David.
faqs.question: Q3

faqs.answer: This verse teaches us to be discerning and cautious, not to blindly trust appearances. It is also to examine our own hearts for similar hypocrisy.

faqs.answer: 'Selah' is a Hebrew term typically interpreted as a pause for reflection or a musical interlude. Here, it emphasizes the gravity of the preceding statement.
